target_title: build: Make all the examples optional

note.body:
I am **not** against making those optional, but I would rather keep these enabled by default though, it's what is used on different documentations on how to use GNOME Kiosk, see for example:

https://docs.redhat.com/en/documentation/red_hat_enterprise_linux/9/html/customizing_the_gnome_desktop_environment/assembly_restricting-the-session-to-a-single-application_customizing-the-gnome-desktop-environment#proc_enabling-single-application-mode_assembly_restricting-the-session-to-a-single-application

note.body:
should probably be 
```
if [....]; then
mkdir -p $XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/bin
cp $EXECDIR/gnome-kiosk-script $XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/bin
EXECDIR=$XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/bin
``` 
(or `$XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/gnome-kiosk/gnome-kiosk-script`)

such so it's not cluttering up the runtime dir root.

target_title: compositor: Add a window configuration file

note.body:
Depends what you mean by "app-id" there.

The app-id available in Wayland xdg-shell translates as wmclass in the public mutter API, so that's covered already.

If you mean the sandbox app-id, then sure, I think that's a good idea, only thing is the sandbox app-id is NULL when not dealing with a sandboxed application, so we need to account for that (just a detail though)

target_title: compositor: Make set-above configurable

note.body:
> maybe just throw this in there and they can land at the same time?

Well, this one already contains the same commits as !50 (to be able to build) so this is already the case actually. I just kept those two separate to ease reviews :smile:

target_title: compositor: Make set-above configurable

note.body:
I don't think so, this is really is about making the windows on the top window group, as under normal circumstances, windows are all placed on the regular window group and stacking is managed by mutter's own heuristics.

So if one sets `set-above=false` for all windows (which is possibly the most likely use case for this), that effectively reverts back to the "normal" behavior. I'm afraid exposing the inverted logic might be confusing.

target_title: compositor: Make set-above configurable

note.body: shouldnt it be called `set-below` and be inverted? auxiliary windows are put above so the application stays below

target_title: compositor: Make set-above configurable
compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body:
Pixel alignment might be something to worry about later, I guess, once things actually become floating point.

There are some times when the size can't be respected already, e.g. scale = 2, X11 coordinate space compat, `window.move_resize_frame(0, 0, 101, 101)` where 101 x 101 isn't an allowed size with wl_surface.buffer_scale = 2. But the API need to know the requests are async and to some degree "hints" anyway, and might not be respected fully, so something baked into the semantics anyway.

target_title: x11 window stack order seems to be unable to be modified

note.body:
That is because of the logic implemented in commit d6d1bfefa, more precisely `kiosk_compositor_wants_window_above()`.

Basically, fullscreen windows are placed below normal sized windows, but once placed that way in the stacking order, it remains immutable.

target_title: compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body:
> I wonder if it would make sense to go and make these floating point already.

Sure, doesn't hurt I guess.

> Another thing to think about what positions and sizes make sense, thinking of pixel grid alignment etc, as well as what sizes a window can have. For example a scale==2 window can sometimes only have even sizes when mutter works in the X11 compatible coordinate space.

However, it uses `meta_window_move_resize_frame()` and `meta_window_move_frame()`, so that's not a problem we (or the script) should care about AFAICS.

target_title: compositor: Add a window configuration file

note.body: (as for the properties, we can only set whatever is supported by the pre-configure values though)

target_title: compositor: Add a window configuration file

note.body: Although, thinking more about it, it's probably more flexible to have a matching mechanism part of the values rather than the section names.

target_title: compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body:
I wonder if it would make sense to go and make these floating point already. We might want to eventually make size and position floats internally for various reasons, and if the API here and potential users are prepared for that it might be useful.

Another thing to think about what positions and sizes make sense, thinking of pixel grid alignment etc, as well as what sizes a window can have. For example a scale==2 window can sometimes only have even sizes when mutter works in the X11 compatible coordinate space.

target_title: compositor: Add a window configuration file

note.body: Ah, sorry for the mis-understanding. The keys here are not only for selecting a window, those won't fit for the approach you have taken. But I was talking about the other ones :)

target_title: compositor: Add a window configuration file

note.body:
That's a different approach though, the keys in https://gitlab.com/bilelmoussaoui/simple-shell#available-options seems to be a free form value (e.g. `[browser]`, `[toolbox]`) whereas here this is the WM class on X11 or XDG app_id on Wayland which allows to quickly search through the keys - The idea was to add the tag to the id eventually to narrow the search and allow for different type of windows per class.

That wouldn't work with additional selection fields within the section itself, as it would be impossible to have two different windows matching the same key.

Not expecting you to add more options to the config file, but while playing with this idea in the past, I ended up adding those options https://gitlab.com/bilelmoussaoui/simple-shell#available-options
Some of them are used to identify a window, the `monitor` one doesn't work that well and requires a timeout for now. The rest might be good to have :)

compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body: Together with a static configuration for the initial state, I see that this approach makes sense.

target_title: compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body:
> I'd imagine it could be something like a D-Bus interface but the service side implemented by the controller, and it having a `Configure()` method that gnome-kiosk would call.

TBH, I am not a big fan of such a solution, I was rather envisioning a static configuration file (to be written) for the static initial configuration (hence the pre-configure hook in mutter), while keeping this control DBus API for dynamic configuration, thing like stress testing the compositor or drivers using scripts.

note.body: There's https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/merge_requests/4076 to tinker with the initial configuration.

target_title: compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body: They are avoidable, but it'd require gnome-kiosk to call into the "controller" to ask it to configure new windows before they show up. I'd imagine it could be something like a D-Bus interface but the service side implemented by the controller, and it having a `Configure()` method that gnome-kiosk would call.

target_title: build: Move to libmutter 16
compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body:
I think race conditions are pretty much unavoidable, and there is no guarantee that the request will not be undone either by the client itself or the user, but the idea is to use the signals `WindowMoved` and `WindowResized` to keep track of the changes as they come in.

We could also add a signal to keep track of the state.

target_title: compositor: Add a remote control DBus API

note.body: A general question of how this API is meant to work is, how do you avoid the client having a different opinion from the controller, and the potential race condition that'd result in when the window is created? As in, avoid the window being visibly mapped in a certain way, then a few frames later being moved/resized to the intended place.

target_title: compositor: Add a remote control DBus API
